desc.size: Medium-sized to large tree, 16 - 24 m tall, trunk diameter 0.5 - 1 m. Trunk crooked, often forked; crown broadly rounded or irregular.

part.partText: whitish or gray, thin, and smooth or with diamond-shaped indentations (lenticels) on young trees, becoming dark gray to black, thick, and deeply fissured at the base.
stout, green, hairy when young, becoming greenish gray or pale brown with dark blotches. Leaf scars crescent-shaped, with 3 bundle scars each.
reddish brown, 3 - 6 mm long, egg-shaped, pointed, hairy.

alternate, with long, densely hairy, flat leafstalks; dark green above, white-hairy beneath (becoming smooth), 5 - 10 cm long, nearly as wide, egg-shaped (leaves in upper crown may be palmate, with 3 - 5 lobes), base straight across or slightly heart-shaped, tip bluntly pointed, margins broadly toothed. Leaves turning yellow in autumn.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy-bracted catkins; male catkins 4 - 8 cm long, cylindrical, thick, anthers purple; female catkins 2 - 5 cm long, slender, stigmas yellow; wind-pollinated.
a 2-valved capsule; borne in drooping catkins 4 - 8 cm long; greenish, flask-shaped, often curved, hairy; seeds light brown with cottony hairs attached; wind-dispersed.

similarSpecies.comments: Populus alba is distinguished from P. balsamifera and P. heterophylla by having flattened leafstalks. Populus x canescens (a hybrid between P. alba and P. tremula) is very similar to P. alba in appearance, but its leaves are usually smaller and toothed, but not lobed. It is best distinguished from other Populus species by its broadly toothed (and sometimes palmate) leaves, which have white-woolly leafstalks and leaf undersides.

speciesPage.flowering: Late March to late April, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: Often found along roads, around old homesites, and in degraded woodlands. Frequently planted and escaping from cultivation. By means of suckers, forms large vegetative colonies that are hard to eradicate. These colonies are not technically considered part of the flora, since the “parent” tree was probably planted.

notes.comments: Introduced from Eurasia, and planted as an ornamental due to its silvery leaves. Populus species as a whole, however, are subject to many diseases and insect pests, such as canker and tent caterpillars, which often kill the tree or make it unattractive. These risks, in conjunction with a water-hungry root system, have made Populus species less desirable for landscape use.

etymology.comments: Populus is the Latin word for poplar. Alba means white.
